s.text: Pollard may have spied for a "friendly" country, but he did a traitor's work.
Pollard may have spied for a "friendly" country, but he did a traitor's work.
He knows whether the charges in the Hersh story are true, and that's why he's in such a quandary.
Another six weeks have come and gone and still there is no decision in sight.

During last year's Wye peace talks, Clinton apparently hinted to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that he would free convicted spy Jonathan Pollard--now serving a life sentence--if Israel signed the peace deal.
He deserves freedom on "humanitarian" grounds: He has served far longer than anyone else convicted of spying for an ally.
In the plea agreement, prosecutors promised not to seek a life sentence, but the judge, after reading a secret account of the damage Pollard had done, sentenced him to life anyway.
In the plea agreement, prosecutors promised not to seek a life sentence, but the judge, after reading a secret account of the damage Pollard had done, sentenced him to life anyway.
In the plea agreement, prosecutors promised not to seek a life sentence, but the judge, after reading a secret account of the damage Pollard had done, sentenced him to life anyway.
In the plea agreement, prosecutors promised not to seek a life sentence, but the judge, after reading a secret account of the damage Pollard had done, sentenced him to life anyway.
In the plea agreement, prosecutors promised not to seek a life sentence, but the judge, after reading a secret account of the damage Pollard had done, sentenced him to life anyway.

Their primary claims are that: 1) Pollard did no real harm to national security; 2) he was well intentioned in spying for our friend Israel; 3) he was unfairly deprived of a trial; 4) he never saw the evidence against him; and 5) the government broke his plea agreement by asking for a life sentence.
As long as these kooks were Pollard's principal support, it was easy for Presidents Bush and Clinton to ignore him.
In fact, prosecutors told Pollard they would ask for a "substantial" sentence and then didn't ask for a life sentence.)
In fact, prosecutors told Pollard they would ask for a "substantial" sentence and then didn't ask for a life sentence.)
